dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so everyone knows, right, like, if things go sideways in the global economy, you just pile into US Treasuries. That's always the answer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so everyone knows, right, like, if things go sideways in the global economy, you just pile into U S Treasuries. That's always the answer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Historically, the safe haven par excellence was the United States, in the form of Treasury bonds backed by the full faith and credit of the US government. As one investment strategist put it back in 2012, When people are worried, all road lead to Treasuries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, well, actually, I don't know if that's still, like, the only answer anymore, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, well, actually, I don't know if that's still, like, the only answer anymore, is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: What? No, it totally is! I mean, in 2008, the financial crisis, everyone freaked out, and where did all the money go? Into the US. Half a trillion, like, boom.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What? No, it totally is! I mean, in two thousand eight, the financial crisis, everyone freaked out, and where did all the money go? Into the U S. Half a trillion, like, boom.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the last three months of 2008, net purchases of US assets reached a half-trillion dollars three times more than that of the preceding nine months combined.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! But, um, that was before a certain president, wasn't it? Like, Trump's kinda... you know, he's shaken confidence in the dollar in a way we haven't really seen.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! But, um, that was before a certain president, wasn't it? Like, Trump's kinda... you know, he's shaken confidence in the dollar in a way we haven't really seen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But this was before the arrival US President Donald Trump, who has managed to undermine confidence in the dollar to an unprecedented degree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, big time! All the attacking international institutions, like, the fiscal irresponsibility, the NATO stuff, uh... It's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, big time! All the attacking international institutions, like, the fiscal irresponsibility, the NATO stuff, uh... It's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to abandoning any notion of fiscal responsibility, Trump has spent his first two years in office attacking international institutions and picking fights with US allies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just Trump, remember 2011? The S&P downgrade because of that debt ceiling fight?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just Trump, remember twenty eleven? The S&P downgrade because of that debt ceiling fight?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, even before Trump, confidence in the dollar suffered a blow in 2011, when Standard & Poors downgraded Treasury securities by one notch in response to a near-shutdown of the US government. That episode was triggered by a standoff between then-President Barack Obama and congressional Republicans over a routine proposal to raise the federal debt ceiling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! So, like, even before, there were cracks. But now, it's like, what, three shutdowns in 2018 alone? For a wall?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! So, like, even before, there were cracks. But now, it's like, what, three shutdowns in twenty eighteen alone? For a wall?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018 alone, the US government was shut down three times, and it remains in a partial shutdown to this day, owing to Trumps demand for funds to build a big, beautiful wall on the border with Mexico.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that proposed law about seizing assets from companies that criticize the US? I mean, whoa.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that proposed law about seizing assets from companies that criticize the U S? I mean, whoa.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, okay, if not the US, then where? Europe? The Euro's the second most used, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, okay, if not the U S, then where? Europe? The Euro's the second most used, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After the dollar, the euro is the worlds most widely used currency.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah, but Germany's slowing, Italy's got banking crisis worries, and don't even get me started on Brexit. Like, the whole, no-deal thing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah, but Germany's slowing, Italy's got banking crisis worries, and don't even get me started on Brexit. Like, the whole, no-deal thing?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Economic growth is slowing, not least in Germany, and the risk of a banking crisis in Italy the eurozones fourth-largest economy looms on the horizon. Worse still is the uncertainty over Brexit, which could prove highly disruptive if the United Kingdom crashes out of the European Union without a divorce agreement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, no-deal Brexit, that's just chaos. So, not Europe. Switzerland, then? Swiss Franc?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, no-deal Brexit, that's just chaos. So, not Europe. Switzerland, then? Swiss Franc?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Too small! Their financial markets, like, they just can't handle the volume.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Too small! Their financial markets, like, they just can't handle the volume.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though its attractions are obvious, Switzerlands financial markets are simply too small to serve as an adequate substitute for the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! So, Japan, then? Massive bond market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! So, Japan, then? Massive bond market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With its abundant supply of government bonds, it is the biggest single market for public debt outside the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But their debt-to-GDP is, like, over 230%! Ours is 88%. Italy, even, is only 130%. It's kinda... scary.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But their debt-to-G D P is, like, over two hundred thirty percent! Ours is eighty eight percent. Italy, even, is only one hundred thirty percent. It's kinda... scary.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The question for portfolio managers, though, is whether it is really safe to invest in a country where government debt exceeds 230% of GDP. For comparison, the public debt-to-GDP ratio in the US is around 88%; and even in troubled Italy, it is no more than 130%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, that's a fair point. What about China? Huge market, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, that's a fair point. What about China? Huge market, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And then there is China, with the worlds third-largest national market for public debt.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, come on, China? It's so tightly controlled! Like, the opposite of a safe haven.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, come on, China? It's so tightly controlled! Like, the opposite of a safe haven.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the Chinese market is so tightly controlled that it is essentially the opposite of a safe haven.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! So, um, basically, there's no safe place left? Investors are just gonna be, like, super jumpy?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! So, um, basically, there's no safe place left? Investors are just gonna be, like, super jumpy?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With secure ports becoming scarce, investors will become increasingly jittery. They will be inclined to move funds at the slightest sign of danger, which will add substantially to market volatility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And that means, uh, increased market volatility. It's gonna be a rough ride, I think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And that means, uh, increased market volatility. It's gonna be a rough ride, I think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They will be inclined to move funds at the slightest sign of danger, which will add substantially to market volatility. Todays rough patch is probably here to stay.
